results.title: The Dehumanizing city...and Hymie Schultz
results.creator_credit: George Justin, Arthur Hiller, Learning Corporation of America and Colombia Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Adapted from the film “The Tiger makes out” with Eli Wallach, the theme here is the modern individual in conflict with complex bureaucratic systems. Waking up one morning to the callous impersonality of big city life, Hymie Schultz, mailman, decides to fight back. Bureaucracy, however, proves more stubborn than he, and at the end of the day defeated and helpless, he retreats, one individual lost among many.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Justin, Arthur Hiller, Learning Corporation of America and Colombia Pictures

results.title: The Death of Socrates
results.creator_credit: Charles W. Russell, Columbia Broadcasting System and Sidney Lumet
results.brief_description: A reconstruction of 399BC in Athens where Socrates, judged guilty of the corruption of youth and of refusal to recognize accepted gods of state faces execution according to Athenian law by drinking poison. Those who had been his main accusers said they did not desire his death but Anytus the politician who caused the trial refuses to reverse his judgement. In prison where a small group of friends have gathered Socrates speaks of the values he has cherished. Without being able to discourse daily about virtue and the greatest good of man he has no reason to live. He drinks poison and as friends weep, dies. Narrated by Walter Cronkite. Cast includes John Cassavetes as Plato, Robert Culp as Xenophon, E.G. Marshall as Aristophanes, Shepperd Strudwic as Crito, Milton Selzer as Melitus and Richard Kiley, Michael Higgins, Barry Jones, Philip Bourneuf, Grant Gordon and Victor Thorley.

results.title: A Day in the death of Donny B
results.creator_credit: Louis Mucciolo, Audio Productions, National Institute of Mental Health (U.S.) and Carl Fick
results.brief_description: A sensitive and frightening portrait of Donny B, a young drug addict, who lives and will probably die in Harlem. To the accompaniament of the song in folk idiom: A Day in the Death of Donny B, we follow him through a day in which he steals enough money for his next “fix”. Shows the utter degradation of a young human being, the hopeless slum environment in which he lives and his situation which can lead to nothing but death.

results.title: The Memphis belle: the story of a flying fortress
results.creator_credit: United States. War Dept. and William Wyler
results.brief_description: The story of the B-17 bomber Memphis Belle on its final mission over Germany to bomb the submarine pens at Wilhelmshaven as told by William Wyler. Shows the 8th Bomber Command air crews being briefed and ground crew preparations. Contains rare wartime footage of actual combat conditions.

results.title: Report from the Aleutians
results.creator_credit: United States. Army. Signal Corps and John Huston
results.brief_description: A documentary of life on a lonely airbase on Adak Island in the Aleutians during World War II. For the men of the base, the enemy was the snow, mud, grey skies and boredom punctuated by an occasional bombing raid. John Huston spent six months on the Island and was nearly killed while filming the climactic raid.

results.title: Pearl Harbour December 7th
results.brief_description: A few cameras were on hand to record the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbour on December 7th 1941, film director John Ford’s unit was given the task of recreating many of the major scenes on Hollywood sound stages. Generations of Americans have witnessed the scenes, not realising the attack is actually Ford’s skilful illusion. Historically, the film is accurate in every detail. Winner of the Academy Award for Documentary Production in 1943.

results.title: Scott of the Antarctic
results.creator_credit: Charles Frend, Sir Michael Balcon and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description: Saga of the ill fated 1912 expedition led by Captain Robert Scott which aimed to be the first to reach the South Pole. Features John Mills, James Robertson Justice and Kenneth Moore.

results.title: Jailhouse rock
results.creator_credit: Richard Thorpe, Pandro S. Berman and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: The story of a hard-working young man, jailed for manslaughter, finds an outlet for his frustrations in music, and eventually becomes a rock star. Considered to be Elvis Presley’s best film performance “Jailhouse Rock” features many songs by Jerry Liebler and Mike Stollen, including “Jailhouse Rock”, “Treat Me Nice”, and “Baby I Don’t Care”.

results.title: Crystallization
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, Dimension Films and Carroll Ballard
results.brief_description: The filming of magnified forms of crystals of common solutions as they are seen forming and then melting in polarized light captures the natural evolving shapes in a kaleidoscope of colour and in an infinite series of abstractions. Visually fascinating, all process were filmed at low magnification. Music by Phil Bishop, microphotography/crystalography by Robert R. Forrester and narration by Marguerite Ray. Suitable for upper secondary level.
